57.
The  provision  of  SFR  to  the  Project  is  justified  in  view  of  the  very  strong  focus  on
reducing poverty in rural areas and its significant support for the Government‘s major efforts on
capacity building to ensure the smooth transfer of administrative and fiscal responsibilities from
the Central level to local governments. The SFR will be used to support investment in process-
oriented activities that involve a broad spectrum of local government and village participants in
preparing  and  implementing  village  development  plans,  and  in  developing  the  capacity  of
communities to decide on the use of local funds for local-level development. These features will
ensure  that  Project-funded  activities  will  be  demand-driven  with  strong  ownership  by  local
communities.

E.

The Executing Agency

58.
The  Directorate  General  of  Rural  Community  Empowerment  will  be  the  Executing
Agency. Its role under the Project is consistent with its new mission under the decentralization
framework to support and facilitate community development planning and coordinating with local
governments and sector agencies in implementing economic growth programs.

59.
Six BPDs will serve as Implementing Agencies under the Project. Since they are taking
full  credit  risk  for  onlending  project  funds  to  CBSLOs,  they  are  also  referred  to  as  Executing
Banks.  Although  the  six  BPDs’  experience  in  microcredit  activities  ranges  from  limited  to
adequate,  they  are  keen  to  participate  in  the  Project  in  view  of  their  changing  role  to  actively
develop financial services in the rural areas of their respective provinces. One of the six BPDs is
a  participant  in  the  ADB-assisted  Microcredit  Project  and  has  gained  experience  in  providing
wholesale  credit  to  nonbank  financial  institutions,  which  in  turn  onlend  funds  to  members,  an
arrangement similar to that proposed for CBSLOs and its members cum borrowers.

F.

Implementation Arrangements

1.

Project Organization and Coordination

 
 
60.
The  key  implementation  responsibility  under  the  Project  will  devolve  to  the  district
government  as  required  by  the  decentralization  laws.  Within  one  month  of  loan  effectiveness,
each district will establish a PIU for day-to-day management of the Project. The project manager
at each PIU will be appointed by the district chief (BUPATI).  Each district will establish a district
advisory group (DAG) within three months of loan effectiveness, to provide advice on measures
for addressing issues affecting timely implementation of the Project. Each DAG will be chaired
by  the  district  chief  and  will  have  the  following  as  members:  the  chairperson  of  the  district
parliament  concerned  and  representatives  from  the  district  planning  agency,  selected  district
technical  support  agencies  (agriculture,  fisheries,  livestock,  trade  and  industry,  etc.),  BPD,
district women’s group, and local credit unions.

61.
Each province will appoint a provincial project manager to provide support and advice to
the  participating  districts.  Selection  of  the  participating  districts  and  subdistricts  has  aimed  at
linking  clusters  of  poor  rural  communities  to  markets  located  at  the  nearby  urban  areas  or
growth centers. Each participating province will establish a provincial coordination office (PCO),
within one month of loan effectiveness, to serve primarily as a coordination center, for reporting
financial  and  physical  progress  coming  from  a  number  of  districts,  and  for  backstopping  the
project  activities  of  the  local  governments.  Within  three  months  of  loan  effectiveness,  each
participating  province  will  establish  a  provincial  advisory  group  (PAG)  to  be  chaired  by  the
governor  of  the  province  and  will  comprise  the  following:  chairperson  of  the  provincial
parliament,  the  head  of  the  provincial  planning  agency  (BAPPEDA),  heads  of  provincial

 21

technical  support  agencies  (agriculture,  fisheries,  livestock,  trade  and  industry,  etc.),  and
representatives of concerned BPDs, women’s groups, and local credit unions.  Each PAG will
advise  on  strengthening  selected  agencies  to  provide  support  for  project  activities  in
participating  provinces  and  districts,  and  on  issues  relating  to  project  coordination.  The  DAGs
and PAGs will meet as necessary and at least once every three months.

62.
Under  the  decentralization  framework,  DGRCE  needs  to  strengthen  its  institutional
capacity  to  serve  in  its  new  role  and  function  to  facilitate  and  monitor  the  progress  of
implementation  of  a  decentralized  and  village  demand-driven  Project.    With  the  day-to-day
management  of  the  Project  devolved  to  the  district  governments,  DGRCE  will  need  to
strengthen its own capability to establish and implement an effective monitoring and evaluation
system. It will establish a project management office (PMO) in Jakarta, within one month of loan
effectiveness. The PMO will be responsible for overall coordination and administration of project
activities,  particularly  for  (i)  submission  to  ADB  of  consolidated  progress  reports  and  other
reports  submitted  by  each  PCO  and  PIU;  and  (ii)  timely  submission  to  ADB  of  unaudited  and
audited accounts of the Project. The PMO will be headed by a full-time senior officer as project
manager, who will be assisted by two full-time assistant PMO project managers (APPMs), one
APPM to facilitate the implementation of part A of the Project and another APPM to facilitate the
implementation of part B and part C. The two APPMs will be assisted by two specialized teams,
comprising DGRCE staff,29 consultants, and NGO facilitators – one team for implementing part
A and another for implementing part B and part C. To provide full liaison and coordination with
all  national  agencies  and  departments  participating  in  the  Project,  a  national-level  project
steering committee (PSC) will be formed, within three months of loan effectiveness. The director
general  of  DGRCE  will  chair  the  PSC  and  will  include  as  members  representatives  from
BAPPENAS;  the  ministries  of  finance,  agriculture,  industry  and  trade  and  cooperatives,  the
Credit  Union  Federation  of  Indonesia,  and  as  appropriate,  local  governments.  The  PSC  will
address  and  resolve  major  policy  issues  affecting  the  Project  and  will  formulate  strategies  for
project implementation (Appendix 5).

2. 

Regional Development Banks

Six BPDs will serve as Executing Banks30 and will implement the credit subcomponent of
63.
the Project to support CBSLO microenterprise development under part B (ii). These banks had
been  set  up  in  each  province  between  1961  and  1965  to  promote  regional  development,
increase regional incomes, and help develop rural institutions. In 1967, BPDs were allowed to
accept  demand  deposits,  grant  short-term  loans,  and  participate  in  equity  investments.  BPDs
are owned by provincial and district governments. The Appraisal Mission assessed the financial
conditions  of  the  six  BPDs,  for  1995  to  1999,  based  on  five  sets  of  financial  indicators  using
CAMEL  rating.31  The  results  indicate  that  all  the  BPDs  have  “satisfactory”  CAMEL  ratings,
except  for  BPD  Central  Sulawesi  (BPDCS)  and  BPD  North  Sulawesi  (BPDNS),  which  were
rated  “less  than  satisfactory”.  However,  after  BPDNS  was  recapitalized  and  underwent
structural changes in 1999, it was rated “satisfactory” at end-1999. Bank Indonesia (BI), which
also  supervises  the  performance  of  the  BPDs,  had  rated  all  the  BPDs  in  March  2000  as
“satisfactory,”  except  for  BPDCS,  which  received  “less  than  satisfactory”  because  of  its  high
nonperforming loan (NPL) ratio (Appendix 6).

64.
test” of senior officers and operational procedures of BPDCS. BPDCS received a passing mark,

agreed on measures (improved collection and writing off bad loans) to reduce the amount of its

3. 

Relending and Onlending Terms

65.
The Borrower would relend part of the ADB funds to the BPDs under a subsidiary loan
agreement  under  the  following  terms  and  conditions:  (i)  an  amortization  period  of  10  years,
including a grace period of 3 years; and (ii) an interest rate of not less than the reference rate
(defined  as  the  average  rate  of  interest  prevailing  for  90-day  rupiah-denominated  Bank
Indonesia  Certificate  [SBI]  over  the  most  recent  three  months).  The  interest  rate  will  be
reviewed annually by ADB and the Government. The foreign exchange risk will be borne by the
Borrower. Each BPD will onlend the funds (taking the credit risk) to qualified CBSLOs that have
registered  as  a  legal  entity  and  fulfilled  other  conditions  as  required  by  the  BPD,  under  an
onlending agreement between the BPD and each CBSLO. The CBSLOs will lend the funds to
their members under a subborrower agreement between the CBSLO and the borrower.

66.
The  BPD  will  onlend  to  CBSLOs  under  the  following  terms  and  conditions:  (i)  an
amortization  period  of  up  to  two  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  three  months;  and  (ii)  an
interest rate of not less than the interest rate payable by BPD under the relevant subsidiary loan
agreement plus a maximum of 8 percent margin. Currently, the interest rate is about 20 percent,
which  is  considered  sufficient  to  cover  the  credit  risk  and  operational  expenses.  The  interest
rate charged by CBSLOs to their borrowing members would be set by the members themselves,
but  would  probably  be  30–33  percent  approximating  the  market  rates  prevailing  in  the  project
area  (Appendix  7).  This  is  considered  sufficient  to  allow  CBSLOs  to  accumulate  capital.  The
credit risk associated with defaults by individual CBSLO members would accrue to the CBSLO,
while  the  credit  risk  arising  from  a  CBSLO  default  would  accrue  to  the  BPD  concerned.  After
successful repayment, CBSLOs can seek additional loans from the BPDs.

4.

Implementation Schedule

The  proposed  Project  will  be  implemented  over  six  years  from  January  2001.  An
67.
indicative  implementation  schedule  is  in  Appendix  8.  The  two  training  programs,  each  for  six
months,  can  be  conducted  in  the  same  village  in  sequence.  The  first  training  program  will
involve capacity building training (under part A) for the whole village. After the first two months,
the  community  will  be  able  to  identify  the  constraints  they  face  in  increasing  income,  their
needs,  and a list of  profitable community microenterprises for the urban markets. At this time,
the  second  training  program  to  form  CBSLOs  under  part  B  of  the  Project  starts,  involving
interested members most of whom are microentrepreneurs. Interest will widen since part B will
address  their  need  for  credit  to  support  their  livelihood  and  microenterprise  activities.  Within
eight  months,  one  cycle  of  training,  involving  capacity  building  and  CBSLO  establishment,  will
have been completed. Villages that successfully complete part A training are eligible to receive
the  village  grant  (amounting  to  $7,800)  enabling  the  community  to  implement  by  themselves

 23

one  of  the  simple  rural  infrastructure  projects  (e.g.,  rehabilitation  of  an  access  road)  they
identified  in  their  village  development  plan.  Subsequently,  eligible  villages  will  be  assisted  to
construct  medium  to  large  civil  works  (Types  I  and  II)  described  in  Appendix  3.  In  the  second
year of Project implementation, BPDs will provide credit for entrepreneurial activities to eligible
CBSLOs,  which  have  shown  at  least  one  year  of  sustained  savings  by  members  and  a  good
record  of  lending  to  members  using  their  own  savings.  Supervised  by  BPDs  and  PMD  staff,
each CBSLO will be required to prepare a profit and loss statement (PLS) annually and conduct
annual meetings to elect officers and to discuss the PLS for transparency.

5.

Flow of Funds

68.
Under  approved  arrangements,  project  loan  funds  will  flow  directly  from  MOF  to  three
levels of management: the PMO in Jakarta, the PCO in the provincial capital, and the PIUs at
the district level. They will be provided as earmarked special funds allocation budgets. Funds for
the credit scheme of part B will be relent by MOF to the BPDs in six provinces for onlending to
CBSLOs.  The  flow  of  funds  from  MOF  to  the  BPDs  will  be  governed  by  a  subsidiary  loan
agreement  between  MOF  and  each  BPD  under  terms  and  conditions  acceptable  to  ADB
(Appendix  9).  The  Government  provided  assurances  that  the  provision  of  funds  from  the
proceeds of the loans, and the corresponding counterpart contributions necessary for financing
Project  activities  would  continue  throughout  Project  implementation  through  the  earmarked
special  funds  allocation,  notwithstanding  (i)  any  reallocation  of  authority  or  responsibility  for
channeling of external assistance, and for provision of corresponding counterpart contributions
between the Central Government, the participating provinces, and the participating districts; or
(ii)  any  requirement  for  provision  of  matching  counterpart  contributions  for  funding  project
activities from participating provinces or participating districts, arising from the implementation of
the provisions of Decentralization Laws 22 and 25.  The Government agreed to regularly update
ADB  on  the  process  of  decentralization  undertaken  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the
decentralization  laws  and  any  relevant  implementation  regulations  issued,  and  to  take  into
account any views ADB expresses on them.32

proposal for award of contract. ADB will be furnished with three copies of (i) an account of the
public  opening  of  bids,  (ii)  a  summary  and  evaluation  of  the  bids,  (iii)  the  proposal  for  award,
and (iv) a draft contract or a draft letter of acceptance. Promptly after award of each contract,
ADB will be furnished with three copies of the contract as executed. ADB will have the right to
review  the  documentation  of  any  contract  awarded  under  LCB  procedures  and  to  refuse  to
finance  such  a  contract  if  it  concludes  that  prequalification  of  the  contractor  or  award  of  the
contract is inconsistent with the Government procurement procedures acceptable to ADB. Civil
works  for  pathways,  storage  sheds,  and  similar  structures  estimated  to  cost  the  equivalent  of
$50,000  or  less  may  involve  the  participation  of  local  communities  and  will  be  awarded  in
accordance with procedures to be agreed upon between the PIU and the community concerned,
and acceptable to ADB.

70.
Utility vehicles, motorcycles, computers, and other office equipment will be purchased by
the PMO, PCOs, and PIUs in their respective locations in Jakarta, and the provincial or district
capitals.  Purchase  of  vehicles  and  motorcycles  will  depend  on  the  availability  of  motor  outlets
and service centers, either in the district or at the provincial capital. Depending on the total cost
of the package, about 91 vehicles and 304 motorcycles will be purchased through international
shopping  for  contracts  below  $500,000,  or  direct  purchase  for  contracts  valued  at  less  than
$100,000. Indicative contract packages and procurement modes for major goods and services
are shown in Appendix 10.

Project.  International  consulting  firms,  in  association  with  domestic  consulting  firms,  will  be
recruited  based  on  ADB’s  Guidelines on the Use of Consultants  and  other  arrangements
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. A total of about 1,054 person-
months  of  consulting  services  will  be  required:  236  (approximately  22  percent  of  the  total)
international, and 818  (approximately 78 percent of the total) domestic. The consulting services
will  be  divided  into  four  packages,  one  package  each  for  parts  A,  B,  C,  and  D  components.
Package  1  will  comprise  about  283  person-months  of  international  and  domestic  consultants;
package 2, about 285; package 3, about 272; and package 4, about 214. The list of consultants
required is in Appendix 11, while the outline terms of reference are in Appendix 12.

The contracts for packages 1, 2, 3, and 4 will include provisions allowing consultants to

8.

Advance Action

73.
Advance action on the preparation of tender documents to reduce the time needed for
engaging  and  fielding  consultants  for  the  Project  is  deemed  essential  to  avoid  any  delays  in
project  start-up.  The  Government  requested  ADB  approval  of  advance  action  in  selecting
consultants to enable the Government to invite proposals from consultants immediately after the
Project  is  approved.  Approval  of  advance  action  was  given  by  Management  at  the  Loan  and
Technical  Assistance  Coordination  Committee.  The  Mission  has  advised  the  Government  that
advance action does not commit ADB to finance the Project. Advance action for engagement of
consultants will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.

9.

Operation and Maintenance

74.
Maintenance  will  be  required  for  all  rural  infrastructure  subprojects,  including  those
constructed with grant funds from part A. Routine maintenance will be carried out by the villages
concerned,  using  a  memorandum  of  agreement  between  the  PIU  and  the  concerned  village
organizations. Most of the maintenance will involve spreading gravel and repairing potholes in
road  surfaces,  painting,  cutting  grass/weeds,  trimming  trees,  cleaning  side  ditches,  placing
culverts, etc. The Project will finance the cost of the materials for the village organizations based
on a survey of needs carried out by the rural infrastructure engineers and villagers, and deliver
the materials on an as-needed basis. The recurrent costs for O&M of civil works will be financed
by the Project on a declining basis as follows: 100 percent in years 1 and 2, 80 percent in year
3, 60 percent in year 4, 50 percent in year 5, and none starting year 6 and onward.

Special Accounts

75.
To  expedite  the  disbursement  of  loan  proceeds,  the  Project  will  open  two  imprest

Government,  ADB  will  deposit  an  initial  amount  not  exceeding  $1.5  million  equivalent  in  an
imprest  account  from  the  OCR  loan  funds,  and  will  deposit  into  a  second  imprest  account  the
amount not exceeding $1.0 million from the ADF loan funds. Funds for the credit subcomponent
under  part  B  of  the  Project  will  be  drawn  from  time  to  time  from  the  imprest  account  for  OCR
funds.  The  statement  of  expenditures    (SOE)  procedures  will  be  used  for  reimbursing  eligible
expenditures not exceeding $50,000 equivalent.

Project Accounts, Audits, and Reports

76.
The  PMO,  PCOs,  and  PIUs  will  maintain  records  and  accounts  to  identify  goods  and

 26

year. The Mission reminded Government representatives and DGRCE of the new ADB policy on

A  framework  for  monthly  reporting  by  electronic  mail  from  the  PMO  to  ADB  using  a  format

An integrated system of data collection and analysis based on PPMS will be designed by

consultants  and  implemented  to  monitor  progress  in  achieving  the  Project’s  objectives.  The

Anticorruption Measures

80.
The  Mission  explained  the  ADB  anticorruption  policy,  particularly  the  section  on  fraud

14.

Midterm Review

81.
A  comprehensive  midterm  review  will  be  conducted  at  the  end  of  year  3  of  project
implementation to assess the progress of physical implementation of the various components:
civil  works  awards;  procurement  of  consulting  services,  vehicles,  and  equipment;  contract
awards  and  disbursement  projections;  and  to  determine  the  need  for  any  change  in  project
scope.  Specifically,  the  performance  of  capacity  building  and  human  resources  development
under part A will be assessed to determine if geographic coverage may be extended from the
six core provinces to 20 new expansion provinces, that show commitment on a voluntary basis.
The review will also examine closely whether the targets set for the full participation of women,
indigenous communities, and the poor are being met or not and whether upward revisions of the
targets  are  warranted.  The  review  will  also  determine  if  both  the  geographic  and  individual
targeting  mechanisms  described  are  adequate  to  bring  the  proportion  of  poor  beneficiaries  to
two thirds of the total project beneficiaries to achieve project objectives. A team of international
consultants will be engaged for two months to conduct the midterm review.

G.

Environmental and Social Measures

1. 

Environment

The  Project  has  minimal  negative  environmental  impact  and  is  rated  as  Category  B
82.
based on ADB’s classification system. An initial environmental examination (IEE) was prepared
to assess two categories of activities likely to have potential environmental impact.

The  first  relates  to  rural  infrastructure  construction.  A  screening  of  24  typical  types  of
83.
proposed infrastructure construction indicates that only six types (involving Type 1 civil works)
warrant  concerns  about  possible  adverse  but  mitigable  impacts.  The  most  probable  impacts
would  be  safety  during  construction,  handling  and  rerouting  of  water,  disposal  of  waste  and
effluent  into  waterways,  and  new  road  alignments  that  might  traverse  or  skirt  cemeteries  or
environmentally sensitive areas such as protected forests. For such activities, specific terms of
reference  will  be  included  in  the  construction  contracts  to  ensure  that  standard  government
environmental procedures (ANDAL) are followed and proper environmental mitigation measures
are  incorporated  in  the  engineering  design.  The  Project  has  a  provisional  sum  in  the
consultants’ contract  to permit contracting for environmental studies and services and engaging
the  appropriate  environment  specialists  to  prepare  terms  of  reference  for  such  contracts,
conduct initial environmental impact evaluation, review proposals from contractors, and develop
an environmental management and impact monitoring plan.

84.
The second category comprises 48 types of microenterprises that may be funded under
part B. Most enterprises are handicrafts and home processing of food products, and individually
are  environmentally  benign.  Thirteen  are  assessed  as  having  potential  adverse  environmental
impacts, with half having slight impacts. The concern is that a geographic concentration of these
types of microenterprises – handicrafts and furniture production using raw materials from nearby
forests  –  could,  in  the  aggregate,  generate  negative  or  indirect  environmental  impacts.  The
Project  will  thus  use  the  environmental  studies  contract  for  technical  assistance  to  prepare
guidelines to be used in the training program for CBSLOs and for the six BPDs to screen loan
proposals  from  CBSLOs.  For  activities  with  possible  aggregate  effects,  the  guidelines  will
include criteria to establish the basis for rejecting the proposals. A consultant will be engaged

 28

six months after the start of project implementation to prepare the environmental management
and monitoring plan, which will be submitted to ADB for approval before any rural infrastructure
and any microenterprise subprojects are approved.  The Government will ensure that any rural
infrastructure subprojects and entrepreneurial activities that have potentially significant adverse
environmental  impacts,  as  determined  by  an  IEE,  will  be  excluded  from  financing  under  the
Project.

2. 

Social Analysis

85.
The Project is to be implemented in six provinces in various agroecological zones: from
settled  agriculture  in  North  Sulawesi  to  upland  and  sometimes  swidden  cultivation  in  Central
Sulawesi,  mixed  tree-crop  farming  in  Southeast  Sulawesi,  and  lowland  river-based  agriculture
and  aquaculture  in  South  Kalimantan.  This  implies  a  large  range  of  settlement  patterns  and
production techniques.  The areas range from the mono-ethnic groups in North Sulawesi to the
complex but established Christian and Muslim communities in Central Sulawesi, coastal Malays
and riverine Dayaks in Kalimantan, a mix of old communities and new settlements in Southeast
Sulawesi, a receiving area of the overflow from the historically disaster-prone South Sulawesi.34
Thus,  the  project  area  is  diverse  in  the  nature  of  resources  to  be  developed  and  in  terms  of
peoples, what they do, and how they do it.

 The districts have been selected because they are poor, and relatively isolated by virtue
86.
of distance, difficult geography, and poor infrastructure.  As a result of this isolation they have
relatively limited access to information about a range of subjects, from production technologies
to prices.  In marketing they tend to be price takers, dependent on either the village trader or a
few  itinerant  buyers.  They  have  also  been  relatively  underserved  by  government  and
development  projects  and 
terms  of  basic  education  and  health  services.  Under
decentralization, their future access to basic services and development will depend on how well
they are able to articulate their needs and priorities to local government. The new situation will
be a significant departure from their experience to date, which has been largely as recipients of
assistance  that,  from  a  local  perspective,  occurred  at  unpredictable  times  and  of  a  type  and
quantity  only  loosely  linked  to  local  needs  and  conditions.  Significant  capacity  building  will  be
required to link these populations, not only economically but politically, to their local leaders and
decisions makers.

in 

87.
The status of women and how they occupy their time differ across the project provinces
and districts.  With the expansion of the education system in the provinces, the participation rate
of girls and boys in basic education has increased. In some districts, Banjar in South Kalimantan
and Donggala in Southeast Sulawesi, girls access to education is limited compared with that of
boys.  In  other  areas  –  Minahasa  in  North  Sulawesi  and  Kendari  in  Southeast  Sulawesi  –  the
reverse  is  true  and  school  participation  rate  of  girls  in  junior  secondary  school  is  about  10
percent  higher  than  that  of  boys.  But  these  are  relatively  late  developments,  since  the  1990s,
and therefore the majority of the adult female population is characterized by levels of education
and levels of literacy lower than those of men. This, combined with other social cultural norms,
implies  that  women  have  far  less  access  in  economic  and  civil  life  than  men.  Nonetheless,
women are active in the labor force.35 Their participation is significantly lower than the national
average in East Kalimantan and North Sulawesi implying that some cultural factors at work may
be keeping women at home. At the same time, the proportion of women seeking work in North
                                                
34 Southeast Sulawesi was originally a sparsely populated corner of South Sulawesi until it became a province of its
own  right  in  the  1960s;  it  has  seen  waves  of  in-migration  in  the  wake  of  various  calamities  in  South  Sulawesi
including famine, the last of which occurred in the 1970s.

35 Labor force participation is the proportion of women who worked or desired to work in the reference period where

work is defined to include both formal and informal sectors and unpaid family labor.

 29

Sulawesi  is  well  over  the  national  average  and  indicates  a  high  unmet  demand  for  income-
generating activities for women. In general, women are economically active in agriculture, food
processing, crafts, and petty trade.

The Project targets primarily the poor through a three-pronged strategy. The Project will
88.
(i)  help  the  poor  secure  their  livelihood  through  improved  infrastructure  and  microfinance
services,  (ii)  empower  the  poor  in  village  economic  and  social  life  through  village-level  social
mobilization, and (iii) influence the political process by increasing the capacity of local officials to
respond to the needs of the poor. The poor are selected through a combination of (i) geographic
targeting,  and  (ii)  targeting  of  poor  individuals  in  the  community.  Geographic  targeting  selects
villages  with  a  poverty  incidence  of  up  to  58  percent,  while  individual  targeting  is  used  to
increase  the  proportion  of  the  total  number  of  poor  beneficiaries  to  two  thirds  of  the  total
beneficiaries. The strategy for targeting the poor is elaborated in the supplementary appendix.

89.
Geographic targeting is accomplished by using the IDT classification of villages having
low  levels  of  infrastructure,  which  is  highly  correlated  with  poverty,  combined  with  the  use  of
local  knowledge-based  criteria.  Individual  targeting  is  carried  out  by  NGO  village  facilitators
hired  under  the  Project.  The  participation  of  the  poor  will  be  further  ensured  by  using  criteria
favoring their participation in the Project: (i) minimum representation of the poor on the village
planning  boards,  (ii)  inclusion  of  a  poverty  impact  assessment  to  be  carried  out  for  all
infrastructure  proposed  for  construction  under  the  Project  to  be  carried  out  by  the  NGO
facilitator, and (iii) incorporation of guidelines in the CBSLO charter for targeting poor members
of the community. In this manner, the Project will increase the proportion of poor beneficiaries to
two  thirds  of  the  total  beneficiaries.  Training  the  local  government  officials  will  increase  the
responsiveness  of  local  governments  responsible  for  design  and  implementation  of  a  poverty
reduction  program  to  the  needs  of  the  poor.  The  construction  of  local  and  village-level
infrastructure  will  help  raise  the  productivity  of  the  poor.  The  formation  of  CBSLOs  will  fill  the
unmet  need of the  poor for  access to savings facilities while enabling access to flexible credit
designed for their needs.

90.
The Project seeks to empower women in the community’s dialogue with Government to
ensure their views and needs are articulated and represented. This is done by promoting their
participation  in  the  development  process  and  requiring  a  minimum  level  of  representation  of
women in the village development councils. Experienced female NGO village facilitators will be
hired.  In  the  government,  women  tend  to  be  underrepresented  at  decision-making  levels
implying gender bias or gender blindness in the development process. The Project will  assess
gender balance in the Executing Agency and increase the pool of women eligible for promotion
through the formal education training program. As women are economically active in the project
area in a variety of activities ranging from small livestock to agriculture processing, handicrafts,
and petty trade, bringing microfinance services closer to the village will enable them to save and
borrow  more  securely,  and  hence,  increase  their  bargaining  power  while  reducing  their
dependence on traditional moneylenders. The formation and training of CBSLOs will be such as
to facilitate the participation of women. Training will be designed for people of low literacy levels.
Village facilitators will pay attention to promoting women’s participation both as members and in
CBSLO  management.  CBSLO  member  rules  will  be  designed  to  be  women  friendly,  and  no
minimum  initial  savings  level  that  might  prove  to  be  a  barrier  to  joining  will  be  established.
Lending levels and terms will be sufficiently flexible to meet the needs of women who tend to be
small entrepreneurs requiring small or short-term working capital.

  H.

Technical Assistance

30

91.
The  Government  noted  that  the  implementation  of  the  Project  and  the  two  new
decentralization  laws  would  start  simultaneously  in  January  2001.  The  need  to  upgrade  and
strengthen the institutional capacity of the district and village governments was underscored to
simultaneously prepare and set up the administrative structures and monitoring arrangement for
accountability and transparency related to their new responsibilities. At issue is the need to set
up a system for disbursement and monitoring of project funds to facilitate compliance with the
specific  financial  monitoring  and  other  reporting  requirements  of  the  Project  and  the
Government. The purpose of the TA is to assist the Executing Agency in developing a system of
disbursing, monitoring, and accounting of project funds in 11 districts in six provinces. The total
cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $1.4  million  equivalent,  of  which  $0.5  million  will  be  the  foreign
exchange cost and $0.9 million equivalent will be the local currency cost. Of the total cost, the
Government has requested that $1.1 million, comprising all the foreign exchange costs and $0.6
million equivalent of the local currency costs, be financed by ADB on a grant basis from ACCSF,
funded by the Government of Japan. The grant financing of $1.1 million constitute 80 percent of
the total TA cost. The Government will finance $0.3 million equivalent or 20 percent of the total
TA cost, mostly in kind. The grant was provided considering the strong focus of the TA on good
governance and sound fiscal management in support of poverty reduction (Appendix 13).

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Financial and Economic Analyses

The financial analysis focused mainly on the financial viability of representative livelihood
92.
enterprises  engaged  in  by  members  of  CBSLOs,  under  the  rural  financial  institutions
subcomponent in part B. This, in turn, served as the basis for determining the financial viability
of the representative microenterprises under the Project. As it is difficult to quantify the benefits
from capacity-building investments carried out under part A, the economic analysis was carried
out  only  for  part  B  taken  as  a  whole.  The  analysis  is  based  on  the  economic  benefits  derived
from  the  representative  microenterprises  and  investment  costs  on  village-level  training,
consulting services for community development, domestic technicians, CBSLO formation, rural
infrastructure  improvement,  rural  infrastructure  operation  and  maintenance,  and  project
management.

1.

Financial Analysis

93.
For the financial analysis, 12 microenterprise models were chosen as representative of
possible livelihood projects that CBSLO members may engage in.  The microenterprises were
selected mainly for the possible type and range of investment costs that CBSLO members may
require, within the limits of their financial capability and capacity to undertake such projects. The
representative  microenterprises  included  investments  in:  (i)  agricultural  activities  such  as
chicken, vegetable, and cocoa production; (ii) food processing such as pineapple candy, palm
sugar,  and  kerupuk  (crackers)  processing;  (iii)  handicraft  making  such  as  the  production  of
furniture, handbags, and palm leaf thatching; and (iv) service enterprises including investments
in  welding  shops,  stores  and  restaurants,  and  transportation  services.  These  representative
microenterprises  require  minimal  capital  investments  and  are  easy  to  implement,  given  the
limited skills, types of resources available, and low level of education of prospective investors.

 31

The  benefit-cost  ratio  (BCR)  for  each  microenterprise  was  estimated  to  determine  its
94.
viability. The analysis indicated that each representative microenterprise was financially sound,
with  calculated  BCRs  greater  than  one.  A  summary  of  the  investment  and  financial  models  of
each  of  these  individual  microenterprises  is  presented  in  Table  3.  Returns  to  labor  are
calculated by dividing revenue less all costs except labor by the amount of labor required.

As the microenterprises are highly vulnerable to significant changes in output and input
95.
prices,  switching  values  were  calculated  to  determine  how  much  output  prices  must  decrease
and production costs must increase to make the BCR equal to one. The analysis indicates that
agricultural production activities required substantial decreases in output prices (10-25 percent)
or  increases  in  production  costs  (14-36  percent)  compared  with  other  types  of  investment
activities to maintain a BCR equal to one. Food processing and most service enterprises were
found  to  be  sensitive  to  changes  in  output  prices  and  production  costs.  The  results  of  the
switching value calculations are in Table A14.1, Appendix 14.

96.
Based  on  the  calculated  streams  of  incremental  benefits  and  investment  costs,  the
calculated  FIRR  before  debt  service  for  the  microenterprises  is  45  percent,  which  adequately
covers  the  33  percent  interest  rate  on  capital  investment.  This  calculation  is  made  over  a  six-
year period taken as the life cycle for the small enterprises used as examples.

2.

Economic Analysis

The economic analysis required a comparison of economic viability in with– and without–
97.
Project situations based on estimates of (i) project investments, (ii) incremental costs associated
with  O&M  of  rural  infrastructure,  and  (iii)  incremental  costs  and  benefits  associated  with
microenterprise  production  activities.  The  economic  evaluation  was  carried  out  for  those
aspects of the Project directly related to the preparation or undertaking of economic activities in
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects. All investments in parts B
and  C,  60  percent  of  total  investments  in  part  D,  and  all  investments  in  part  A  related  to

 32

community  development  –  consulting  services,  village-level  training,  and  facilitators  –  were
included in the analysis.

98.
The  resulting  net  present  value  showed  that  part  B  is  expected  to  generate
approximately  Rp102  billion  (about  $14.6  billion)  for  the  economy.  The  Project  is  expected  to
realize an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of about 17 percent.

99.
 Switching values indicate that the EIRR is not highly sensitive to decreases in prices of
microenterprise products or to increases in project investment costs. For the EIRR to fall to 12
percent, the level assumed to be the economic opportunity cost of capital, prices need to fall by
23  percent  while  investment  costs  need  to  increase  by  about  30  percent.  Both  price  and
investment costs need to decrease and increase, respectively, by about 13 percent to maintain
an EIRR equal to 12 percent  (Appendix 14).

100.
The  Project  will  benefit  both  economic  and  social  development  by  ensuring  that  the
targeted  districts,  villages,  and  individuals  have  the  benefit  of  improved  local  administrative
capability,  support  for  participatory  planning  and  implementation  of  improvements  in  rural
infrastructure,  and  access  to  financial  services  and  microenterprise  support.  The  poor  in
particular  will  benefit 
the
empowerment of rural village communities.

Environment

101. Since 
two  categories  of  project  activities  (civil  works  and
entrepreneurial  activities)  could  have  potential  environmental  impact,  an  environmental
management and monitoring plan will be prepared. The services of an environmental specialist
will  be  engaged  at  the  start  of  project  implementation  to  prepare  the  plan.  Private  sector
contractors,  the  PIU,  and  village  staff  involved  in  the  construction  of  civil  works  under  part  C,
and CBSLO and BPD officials involved in the processing and approval of subborrower loans for
entrepreneurial  activities  under  part  B  will  actively  participate  in  managing  and  monitoring  the
environment. This will ensure that any potential environmental impact is minimized and project
activities fully conform to the environmental guidelines of the Government and ADB.

C.

Social Dimensions

102.
The Project is designed to link underserved villages commercially to growth centers and
to  institute  a  process  whereby  all  villagers,  including  the  poor,  are  able  to  plan  village-level
development and form self-help savings and loan organizations. In this regard, the Project has
several  important  social  features.  It  targets  IDT  villages:  almost  all  the  72  subdistricts  to  be
covered by the  Project have a preponderance of IDT villages, which is the best available proxy
at  the  design  stage  to  locate  the  Project  in  poor  rural  areas  in  the  six  provinces.  Based  on
information  obtained  during  the  feasibility  study  and  a  sample  of  village  socioeconomic
profiles,36 it is estimated that over half of the 750 villages to be covered are IDT villages. Most
households in these villages are at or below the poverty line, estimated at Rp670,000 (less than
$100)  per  annum  in  year  2000  values.  Interviews  conducted  during  the  TA  feasibility  studies
period and during the Loan Fact-Finding and Appraisal Missions confirmed that many, if not the
majority, of project participants would be those at or below the poverty line.

                                                
36 A sample of about 30 village profiles was obtained during field reconnaissance.

 33

To  ensure  that  more  reliable  and  poverty-sensitive  criteria  are  used  and  to  provide  an
103.
opportunity for the DGRCE field staff and for potential target beneficiaries to participate in the
selection process, it was decided not to finalize village selection during the project design stage.
Rather, the villages would be selected in year 1 of project implementation, following a rapid rural
appraisal  of  each  subdistrict  and  consultation  (using  focus  group  interview  techniques)  with  a
sample of potential beneficiaries.

104.
The Project will make a significant investment in process-oriented activities to involve a
broad  spectrum  of  local  government  and  village  participants  in  identifying,  preparing,  and
implementing  village  development  plans  and  in  forming  and  operating  the  CBSLOs.  Such
activities will account for about 20 percent of the total project cost. The investment is expected
to  generate  significant  positive,  although  intangible,  social  impacts:  inclusion  of  target
beneficiaries alongside local government officials in making key decisions concerning the use of
funds  for  local  development  at  the  level  where  they  matter  most.  This  feature  will  ensure  that
Project-funded  activities  will  be  demand-driven  and  “owned”  by  local  communities,  thus
underscoring  the  purpose  of  the  decentralization  laws.  More  specifically,  through  the
community-based  planning  mechanisms,  Kelompok  Kerja  Pembangunan  Masyarakat  and
CBSLOs, village participants would develop and apply planning and management skills for local
development. It is expected that these villagers, if not themselves poor people, would also be in
a position to advocate and address the interests of the poor and any disadvantaged groups in
the  village  institutional  context  as  well  as  within  the  new  local  government  framework.  The
Project would thus empower the targeted rural communities by providing them the capabilities to
put social meaning into the government decentralization process.

1.

Gender Considerations

105. Reconnaissance  studies  and  other  information  gathered  during  the  feasibility  studies
indicate  that  women  and  particularly  relatively  poor  women  form  the  majority  of  micro-
entrepreneurs and savers in rural communities in the six provinces. Women from several ethnic
groups in Sulawesi have established a strong tradition in producing and selling in local markets
handicrafts  such  as  mats,  stone  jewelry  (with  distinctive  designs  of  their  ethnic  groups),  and
processed foods from their home gardens. This observation is mirrored in the list of proposals
obtained from feedback interviews with potential target beneficiaries – the majority involved food
or  product  processing  and  small  businesses  commonly  operated  by  women.  These  findings
provide  assurance  that  women  will  benefit  directly  from  the  Project’s  investments  in
microenterprise  development,  provided  care  is  taken  that  this  assumption  is  borne  out  during
project implementation, and that poor women are not outcompeted by better-off members of the
CBSLOs in seeking loan support. Training for CBSLOs will emphasize inclusion of women in all
aspects of operations. Lending policies will be tailored to the demand of women entrepreneurs
and  skewed  in  favor  of  poor  women.  The  project  consultants  will  work  out  the  details  during
implementation of the CBSLOs formation subcomponent.

2.

Indigenous People’s Plan

106. An  indigenous  people’s  plan  was  prepared.  The  Mission  assessed  the  Project  as
essentially  neutral  for  indigenous  people.  It  will  not  have  a  negative  effect  on  their  cultural  or
political  norms  or  affect  their  access  to  land  or  other  resources.  The  empowerment  process
under part A will be beneficial to marginal communities that wish to participate and which may
have been neglected in the previous centrally planned development process. Local communities
will  be  given  greater  opportunities  and  increased  skills  to  plan,  manage,  and  decide  on  the
content and direction of their own development plans. Part of the subdistrict development plan
will  be  identifying  and  mapping  marginal  or  isolated  communities  and  groups.  In  general,  the

 34

Project  is  expected  to  bring  positive  benefits  to  indigenous  people  by  giving  them  access  to
mainstream services and to improved governance practices (Appendix 15).

D. 

Impact on Poverty

1. 

Poverty Reduction

107.
The  Project  targets  the  poor  by  helping  them  secure  their  livelihood  through  improved
microfinance services and rural infrastructure, empowering them in village economic and social
life  through  village-level  social  mobilization,  and  influencing  the  political  process  by  increasing
the  capacity  of  local  officials  to  respond  to  the  needs  of  the  poor.  The  Project  promotes  the
participation  of  women  at  every  step  of  this  process  and  brings  microfinance  services  to  the
village,  enabling  women  to  save  and  obtain  credit  more  securely,  and  thus  reduce  their
dependence  on  moneylenders.  The  Project  will  also  benefit  about  4,500  community  leaders
trained in participatory approaches, management skills, and financial management.

The Project aims to reduce poverty by increasing the incomes of about 425,000 people,
108.
or 85,000 families, through microenterprise and small enterprise development. Of these, about
370,000 people, or 74,000 families, are expected to move above the poverty line. The Project
will directly benefit about 550,000 people, or 110,000 families, in the project area, equivalent to
4  percent  of  the  population,  through  capacity  building  for  local  government,  employment,  and
enterprise  development.  About  1.1  million  people,  or  220,000  families,  in  750  villages  in  11
districts  will  benefit  from  improved  rural  infrastructure  enabling  them  access  to  markets  in
nearby urban centers or growth corridors for their products and to social and health services. An
estimated  185,000  jobs  will  be  generated  from  project  activities.  The  Project  will  extend  the
geographic scope of its community training and community empowerment, under part A, to an
additional  40  districts  from  20  expansion  provinces  following  successful  midterm  evaluation  of
the  Project.  The  community-based  planning  mechanism  introduced  are  key  to  instituting  good
governance practices in the community development process.

2.

Nonquantifiable Benefits

The  Project  addresses  social  exclusion  issues  that  when  resolved,  will  bring  non-
109.
quantifiable  benefits  to  the  rural  communities  and  the  poor.  The  community-based  planning
mechanisms to  be  introduced under  part A will involve democratic practices and processes to
anchor  decision  making  over  what  and  how  resources  would  be  used  for  communal  benefit.
Participants will be elected by villagers and proposals for the village development plans will be
considered and approved by elected representatives (village-level and community-level), in an
intervillage  forum.  These  mechanisms  are  key  to  instituting  good  governance  practices  in  the
community  development  process.  In  that  respect,  the  Project  will  help  effect  the  democratic
underpinnings  of  decentralized  government  as  promulgated  by  the  two  decentralization  laws.
The  trainees  will  include  government  officials  in  the  subdistricts  and  districts  where  these
processes  currently  are  weakest.  The  Project  is  envisaged  to  strengthen  the  village
communities’  ability  to  articulate  and  lobby  for  support  for  their  development  plans  as  well  as
their  respective  district  governments’  ability  to  respond  to  their  demands.  As  the  Project  will
target  poor  villages,  this  capacity-building  process  will  directly  benefit  the  poor  by  providing
them  a  means  to  draw  the  attention  of  local  government  and  resources  to  their  development
needs.  Furthermore,  the  Project  criteria  that  women  be  adequately  represented  in  the
institutions  and  training  activities  to  be  sponsored  will  mean  that  women  as  well  as  men
participate in and benefit from the process.

 35

Increased  opportunities  for  diploma  and  degree  training  under  the  human  resource
110.
development  subcomponent  will  widen  the  base  of  trained  local  government  workers.  About
1,634  staff  in  subdistricts  and  districts  will  be  trained  for  a  three-year  diploma  or  a  four-year
bachelor’s  degree  under  the  Project.  This  should  improve  their  capability  for  community
development  work,  with  subsequent  positive  impacts  on  their  morale  and  productivity.  For
another 139 senior officials who would receive postgraduate training locally and overseas, the
opportunity to attend universities will widen their experience and provide new insights into how
development  planning  is  carried  out  in  Indonesia  and  in  the  region.  It  will  also  allow  them  to
learn from the experiences of others.

111.
The  formation  of  community  members  into  CBSLOs,  together  with  associated  training
and support, will empower them by ensuring their representation and participation in sustainable
village development and resource management activities. Membership in the CBSLOs will also
(i) improve access of the participants to financial services for livelihood or supplemental income-
generating activities; (ii) strengthen their income-earning capacities; and (iii) equip them with the
necessary  skills  in  small  enterprise  management  and  entrepreneurship  in  a  wider  variety  of
occupations, thus widening their financial options. The heightened awareness of women of their
important role in the success of project initiatives, the enhancement of their skills for livelihood
development  activities  and  credit  and  savings  mobilization,  and  their  empowerment  for
community  leadership  and  resource  management  activities  are  anticipated  to  be  important
project  achievements.  Similarly,  for  both  men  and  women,  improvement  in  confidence  and
morale with direct participation in both planning and implementing village plans and the Project
can produce lasting change.

The provision of basic social infrastructure facilities (e.g., potable water supply, drainage,
112.
and community halls) will improve the general health of the community residents as a result of
better  personal  hygiene  and  sanitation.  Most  of  all,  investments  in  rural  roads  will  open
opportunities for poor people in villages to market their produce at better prices and to access
products  and  services.  Probably  no  other  single  form  of  investment  creates  the  same  level  of
nonquantifiable  benefits  as  small  rural  roads  connecting  villages  to  the  major  transport  and
communication systems.

E. 

Risks

113.
If  implemented  as  planned,  decentralization  of  administrative  and  financial  functions  is
expected  to  improve  project  implementation  in  line  with  the  envisaged  improvement  in  the
efficiency  of  delivery  of  public  services.  In  addition,  the  Project  will  assist  in  the  general
democratization  process  through  the  capacity-building  program  under  part  A  of  the  Project,
which is the essential adjunct to decentralization. Increasing participation by ordinary (including
poor)  people  in  the  decision-making  process  and  the  corresponding  pressure  from  them  for
transparency will greatly assist in combating the dangers from malfeasance and corruption.

114.
The  prevailing  ambiguity  about  the  precise  nature  of  the  division  of  administrative  and
financial  responsibilities  between  different  levels  of  government  for  implementing  rural
development  programs  poses  two  types  of  risk  in  project  implementation.  First,  would  the
Central  Government  leave  the  entire  counterpart  financial  responsibility  for  implementing  the
Project  on  the  participating  province  or  districts?  Second,  given  the  ensuing  changes  in  the
system of fiscal transfers from the Central to the regional governments, including the channeling
of  external  assistance,  would  the  participating  provinces  and  districts  be  expected  to  shoulder
the financial burden of servicing and repaying the ADB loans for the Project? The Government
has  provided  assurances  that  limit  the  uncertainties  in  the  financial  and  institutional
arrangements for project implementation that may arise from the division of administrative and

 36

financial  responsibilities  between  different  levels  of  government.  The  Government  assured  the
ADB Appraisal Mission that such changes are internal to the Government and that the Central
Government  as 
financial
commitment to the Project.

the  Borrower  would  remain  responsible 

the  counterpart 

for 

115. As  with  most  projects,  the  timely  availability  of  counterpart  funds  will  be  necessary  for
success  as  well  as  the  availability  of  counterpart  personnel  at  national,  provincial,  and  district
levels.  The  Government’s  continued  commitment  to  improving  the  capacity  of  regional
governments  and  to  poverty  reduction  should  ensure  that  the  necessary  resources  are
forthcoming.  The  Government  has  agreed  that  annual  budgets  will  be  provided  to  the  Project
through  special  allocations  to  ensure  timeliness  of  funds  needed  for  implementation,  and  an
expanded  formal  education  program  will  widen  the  base  of  trained  local  workers  at  subdistrict
and  district  levels,  thus  addressing  the  concerns  about  availability  and  quality  of  counterpart
staff.

116. Within  the  Project  itself,  there  will  always  be  risks  associated  with  investment  in
microenterprises  even  though  their  finances  appear  reasonably  robust.  Much  also  will  depend
on the organization and capacity of the CBSLOs and especially on the commitment of CBSLO
members. For this reason, the Project has provided for NGO facilitators, most of whom will be
drawn  from  NGOs  in  the  area  concerned,  including  existing  credit  unions  where  available,  to
provide  in-depth  contact  and  discussion  encouraging  prospective  beneficiaries  to  actively
participate in CBSLO formation. The Mission at appraisal had assessed that suitable NGOs and
NGO facilitators are available in the project area.

The  financial  and  economic  risks  associated  with  microenterprise  development  are
117.
inevitably  present,  but  the  financial  and  economic  analyses  indicate  a  reasonable  degree  of
robustness.

VII. 

RECOMMENDATION

I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loans  for  the  Community  Empowerment  for  Rural
121.
Development Project (Project) would comply with the Articles of Agreement of ADB and, acting
in the absence of the President, under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement
of ADB, I recommend that the Board approve:

(i) 

the loan in various currencies equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 38,752,000 to
the Republic of Indonesia for the Project, and with a term of 32 years, including a
grace  period  of  8  years,  with  an  interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1  percent  per
annum during the grace period and 1.5 percent per annum thereafter, and such

 38

other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth
in the draft Loan Agreement (Special Operations) presented to the Board;

(ii) 

the loan of $65,000,000 from ADB's ordinary capital resources to the Republic of
Indonesia for the Project, and with a term of 25 years, including a grace period of
6  years,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB's  pool-based
variable  lending  rate  system  for  US  dollar  loans,  and  such  other  terms  and
conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft
Loan Agreement (Ordinary Operations) presented to the Board; and

(iii) 

the provision of technical assistance in an amount not exceeding the equivalent
of  $1,100,000  to  the  Government  of  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  the  Financial
Management System from ACCSF.

RURAL INFRASTRUCTURE SUBCOMPONENT

A. 

Brief Description of the Subcomponent

The rural infrastructure component will improve the ability of the general population and
1.
entrepreneurs  in  selected  subdistricts  and  villages  to  develop,  expand,  and  market  their
products  by  constructing  or  improving  rural  infrastructure.    The  rural  infrastructure,  in  most
cases, will be for the common good. It will link a village to nearby villages and connect all to the
growth  centers.    The  various  infrastructure  subprojects  will  be  selected  using  a  participatory
approach that considers the needs of the villages or the common good of a cluster of villages.

B. 

Types of Infrastructure Subprojects

2.

The Mission considers three types of infrastructure subprojects relevant to the Project:

Type I

Type II

Type III

Rehabilitate access roads
Village markets
Village offices
Sea walls
Medium-size warehouses

New roads
Bridges/box culverts
Jetties
Deep tubewells for
    water supply1
Large warehouses
Electric distribution 
    lines to national electric
    company (PLN)
Fish auction markets
 

Pathways
Drying floors
Storage sheds
Pump houses
Community latrines
Village drains
Meeting halls
Bus shelters
Village roads
Terracing
Shallow wells
Culverts
Water distribution pipes

3.

The types of rural infrastructure and actual construction procedures are as follows:

Type  I.  Contracted  works  using  only  district  licensed  construction  contractors  who  will
4.
supply  the  heavy  equipment,  expertise,  and  materials  required.    However,  the  contractor  will
engage a large complement of village labor from the villages concerned.  Type I subprojects are
relatively complex and will require the services of the district public works offices in association
with  the  project  implementation  units  (PIUs)  for  investigations,  survey,  design,  and  technical
specifications. District-level public works officers will assist the PIUs in awarding contracts and
supervising  the  work.  Type  I  civil  works  are  expected  to  cost  about  $100,000-$250,000  using
local competitive bidding (LCB) procedures and local labor, except for the 11 core subprojects
estimated to cost $500,000 or less.

5.
Type  II.  Contracted  works  using  prequalified  licensed  construction  contractors  who  will
supply  the  heavy  equipment  and  expertise.  However,  only  village  labor  for  the  villages
concerned will be employed.  Materials will be purchased by the PIU and supplied directly to the
villages concerned.  Type II subprojects are moderately complex and will require the services of
the district public works offices for design and technical specifications, and to assist the PIUs in
awarding  contracts  and  supervising  the  work.  They  cost  about  $50,000-$100,000  using  LCB
procedures and local labor.

                                                
1 These deepwells will provide drinking water to several villages. Deep tubewells for irrigation or other enterprises will

be conducted through the credit program with Bank Pembangunan Daerah (regional development bank).

 44045

Appendix 3, page 2

6.
Type  III.  These  are  simple,  selp-help  projects  and  will  use  only  village  labor  under  the
control  of  a  construction  supervisor.  The  PIUs  will  directly  supply  materials  to  the  villages
concerned.  Laborers and supervisors will be paid for their labor at a lower labor scale, i.e., 70
percent  of  the  average  subdistrict  labor  rate.    Thus,  villagers  will  have  a  minimum  30  percent
stakeholders equity in the civil works.  The works will be contracted, through a memorandum of
agreement between the PIUs and the village, most probably as a lump sum contract or possibly
a  daily  rate  contract.  The  village  laborers  will  be  paid  by  the  village  organization  with  funds
provided by the PIU and monitored by PIU staff.  Type III civil works are expected to cost less
than $50,000.

7.

In all three types of subprojects, the affected villagers will be the primary source of labor.

C. 

Selection Criteria for Rural Infrastructure Subprojects

Appropriate  rural  infrastructure  subprojects  at  the  village  level  will  be  selected  on  the

8.
following criteria:

The subproject is located in a project subdistrict.
A new community planning organization has been established and is functioning
in the participating village.
The subproject is for the common good of the participating villages.
The  subproject  is  on  the  priority  list  of  work  to  improve  the  quality  of  life  and
commerce  in  the  participating  villages  and  is  connected  to  the  development  of
nearby villages with commercial links to urban growth centers.
For type I and type II subprojects, the PIU and affected villages will enter into a
memorandum  of  agreement  defining  the  responsibilities  of  all  parties,  including
public works offices and others.
For  type  III  subprojects,  the  PIU  and  the  villagers  will  enter  into  a  similar
memorandum of agreement.
The  infrastructure  will  serve  more  than  one  village  and  link,  in  some  way,  rural
urban commercial centers.
Investigations,  surveys,  designs,  drawings,  technical  specifications,  and  cost
estimates can be prepared in about three months and approved by the PIU and
village organizations concerned.
Concerned  government  agencies,  district  planning  agency  and  district  public
works office, have been consulted and have agreed to the intervention.
Prior  to  starting  construction,  rural  infrastructure  engineers  are  engaged  at  the
district  level  and  nongovernment  organization  construction  specialists  are
engaged to supervise the works.
Type I subprojects should range in cost between $100,000 and $250,000; type II
subprojects,  about  $50,000-$100,000;  and  type  III  subprojects,  less  than
$50,000.
The  concerned  village  organization  enters  into  an  operations  and  maintenance
memorandum of agreement with the PIU.  Materials will be provided by the PIU
and the villages will provide labor, free of charge on a self-help basis.

(xiii)  Subprojects  with  potentially  adverse  environmental  impacts,  as  determined  by
an initial environmental examination, and which cannot be easily mitigated will be
excluded from the Project.

 44046

Appendix 3, page 3

D. 

Selection of 11 Core Subprojects in 11 Districts

9.
Eleven districts in the six provinces will select 11 core subprojects to start implementing
the Project in the first two years.  The subprojects will aim to assist commercial activities, as well
as  improve  the  lives  of  the  people  in  the  villages  concerned,  and  should  be  aimed  for  the
common  good.  The  core  subprojects  are  expected  to  include  rehabilitation  of  road  links  and
construction of bridges/box culverts on those road links so as to move commerce and improve
transportation  links  for  general  purposes.  The  roads  will  serve  several  villages  and  be
connected  to  the  commercial  areas  of  growth  centers.    The  maximum  length  of  road  will  be
about  2-3  kilometers  and  will  include  2-3  drainage  crossings  (bridges  or  box  culverts).  Each
subproject is expected to cost $500,000 or less.

SIX REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT BANKS

A. 

Introduction

1.
To  support  the  development  of  community-based  savings  and  loan  organizations
(CBSLOs) in the project area, six regional development banks (Bank Pembangunan Daerah or
BPD)  will  serve  as  Executing  Banks.  CBSLOs  will  be  formed  in  each  participating  village  to
mobilize savings, provide financial services among the members, and manage small loans for
enterprise  development.  The  six  BPDs  are  BPD  Central  Kalimantan,  BPD  East  Kalimantan,
BPD  South  Kalimantan,  BPD  Central  Sulawesi,  BPD  North  Sulawesi,  and  BPD  Southeast
Sulawesi.

2.
The BPDs are owned by the provincial and local governments. They were established in
1961-1965  to  promote  regional  development,  increase  regional  income  sources,  and  help
develop rural financial institutions. In 1967, an act allowed the BPDs to accept demand deposit,
grant  short-term  loans,  and  participate  in  equity  investments,  thereby  expanding  their  powers
and enabling them to compete with regular commercial banks. The BPDs have headquarters in
the  provincial  capital,  and  branches  in  the  districts.  Not  all  BPDs  have  branches  in  the
subdistrict.  BPD  South  Kalimantan  has  a  strong  background  in  microfinance  gained  from  the
ADB’s  Microfinance  Project;  the  five  other  BPDs  have  been  involved  in  Government-funded
microfinance schemes.

B. 

Performance of the Six BPDs

1. 

Financial Indicators

3.
The assets of the six BPDs increased by 15.8 percent annually during the last five years.
Their combined total assets amounted to Rp1,582.4 billion ($226 million equivalent) at the end
of  1999.  The  growth  in  assets  is  attributed  to  the  BPDs’  profitable  operation  as  well  as  to
additional capital infusion to one BPD from the owners.

4.
In terms of profitability, all six BPD performed well during the past five years, except for
BPD  North  Sulawesi,  which  barely  made  a  profit  and  did  not  meet  the  acceptable  return  on
equity (ROE) for three years. As a result, BPD North Sulawesi was recapitalized and underwent
major  structural  changes  in  1999.  Its  profitability  slightly  improved  by  the  end  of  1999  when  it
posted a 9 percent ROE. The total assets, total equity, and net income after tax of the six BPDs
from 1995 to 1999 are in Table A6.1.

5.
Combined  with  the  growth  in  assets,  the  six  BPDs  have  increased  their  interbank
placements and reduced their loans receivable. On the average, the six BPDs loan portfolio is
only 34 percent of their total productive assets. A substantial portion of their productive assets is
in  interbank  placements  rather  than  in  loans  receivable.  Interbank  placements  are  temporary
investments  and  are  also  a  liquidity  buffer.  Because  of  the  financial  crisis  in  1997,  it  was
relatively  safer  to  put  money  in  other  banks  than  to  extend  loans.  However,  the  demand  for
loans  is  expected  to  increase  and  so  the  loan  portfolio  is  also  expected  to  grow,  as  the
Indonesian  economy  recovers  from  the  shock  of  1997  and  interest  rates  continue  on  a
downtrend.  Table  A6.2  shows  the  distribution  of  the  productive  assets  of  the  six  BPDs  by  the
end of 1999.

In terms of growth, the combined loan portfolio of the six BPDs increased in 1996 and
6.
1997,  but  contracted  by  3.9  percent  in  1998,  compared  with  the  1995  level.  Only  BPD  South
Kalimantan and BPD Southeast Sulawesi were able to significantly increase their loan portfolio.
All six BPDs were affected by the financial crisis and experienced collection problems. During
the crisis, lending activities slowed down but lending showed signs of picking up in 1999. Table
A6.3 shows the loan portfolio of six BPDs during the last five years.

3.

Quality of Assets

8.
Bank Indonesia monitors monthly the BPDs productive assets ratio (PAR) and the extent
of the nonperforming loans. The Bank requires all BPDs to make proper provisions for possible
losses  from  their  productive  assets  so  that  their  financial  statements  will  reflect  their  true
financial condition.

9.
The  Mission’s  analysis  of  the  quality  of  assets  of  the  BPDs  indicates  a  rating  ranging
from satisfactory to excellent, except for BPD Central Sulawesi which scored poorly because of
its  large  nonperforming  loan  portfolio  —  equivalent  to  more  than  half  of  its  Rp15  billion  loan
accounts by the end of 1999. BPD Central Sulawesi informed the Mission that it has not written
off  these  accounts  because  of  the  ongoing  efforts  to  collect  on  them  or  to  foreclose  them.
However, in computing the PAR, these past due loans are treated as lost for conservatism. The
rating of the BPDs in terms of productive assets ratio is shown in Table A6.5.

C. 

Mission’s Assessment of the Financial Conditions of Six BPDs

1. 

CAMEL Rating

10.
The Mission used the CAMEL instrument in assessing the financial conditions of the six
BPDs because it reconciles the short-term and long-term measures of performance. CAMEL is
the  acronym  for  capital  adequacy,  asset  quality,  management,  earnings  history,  and  liquidity
management.  CAMEL  was  created  in  1979  to  enable  North  American  bank  regulators  to
measure the financial and management soundness of US commercial lending institutions, using
key ratios, indicators, and institutional policies and procedures.

11.
The average CAMEL scores of the six BPDs for 1995-1999 indicate that they were either
in  good  or  satisfactory  financial  condition,  except  for  BPD  Central  Sulawesi,  which  obtained  a
“less  than  satisfactory”  rating  (Tables  A6.6  and  A6.7).  The  main  reason  for  this  rating  was  its
high  ratio  of  nonperforming  loans  (para.  21).  In  1999,  BPD  North  Sulawesi  was  recapitalized
and  underwent  structural  changes.  As  a  result,  it  obtained  a  “satisfactory”  rating  at  the  end  of
1999.

Appendix 6, page 5

2. 

Capability to Deliver Credit Services

The  six  BPDs  have  adequate  staff  to  deliver  credit  services  to  the  Project  CBSLOs.
13.
However, delivery to the CBSLOs will require a different orientation and the BPD staff that will
be assigned to the Project will need to undergo training.

3. 

Improving BPD Central Sulawesi Operations

14.
The Mission assessed the effect of the nonperforming loans on the future operations of
BPD  Central  Sulawesi.  The  results  indicate  that  BPD  Central  Sulawesi  will  continue  to  be  a
viable  bank.  With  more  persistent,  regular,  and  determined  effort  to  collect  loan  accounts,  its
financial position can be significantly improved.

4.

Effect of Proposed Relending by MOF to Six BPDs

The respective capital1 of all the six BPDs will remain adequate even after disbursement
15.
of  the  entire  $2.5  million  MOF  credit  loan  to  each  BPD.  Among  the  six  BPDs,  BPD  Central
Sulawesi has the smallest capital at Rp9.8 billion ($1.4 million). Its capital adequacy ratio, which
stood  at  38  percent  at  the  end  of  1999,  would  have  increased  to  41  percent  by  year  2001
without  the  MOF  credit  loan.  With  the  $2.5  million  loan,  its  capital  adequacy  ratio  can  still  be
maintained within the 34-38 percent level, which is considered more than sufficient. Its loan-to-
deposit ratio will increase from 43 percent to 104 percent, which is within acceptable standards,
after it has onlent the funds to the project CBSLOs.

D.

Bank Indonesia’s Assessment of the Six BPDs

Bank  Indonesia  assessment  of  the  six  BPDs  in  March  2000  indicates  that  all  are
16.
financially sound. However, BPD Central Sulawesi received a rating of “less than satisfactory”
mainly because of its high ratio of nonperforming loans. This BPD continues to operate normally
and accept deposits from the public.

17.
The  Mission  was  informed  that,  considering  the  above  rating,  Bank  Indonesia  had
conducted a “fit and proper test” of senior officers and operational procedures of BPD Central
Sulawesi.  The  result  of  the  test  gave  BPD  Central  Sulawesi  a  passing  mark.  Bank  Indonesia
and BPD Central Sulawesi have agreed on measures to reduce the amount of nonperforming
loans in one year to improve the BPD’s Bank Indonesia classification.

E. 

Financial Projections for BPDs

18.
The  Mission  examined  the  future  financial  viability  of  the  six  BPDs  based  on  CAMEL
rating for 2001–2006. The assumptions used common to all the BPDs are summarized in Table
A6.8.  The  BPDs  were  assumed  to  maintain  a  cash  balance  equivalent  to  1  month  operating
expenses plus 5 percent of demand liabilities. Excess funds were assumed to be placed in other
banks as call loans or plain deposits.

Based on historical data for each BPD as well as in the aggregate, the Mission projected
19.
the growth rates of the loan portfolio as well as the demand liabilities of the BPDs. BPD Central
Sulawesi  was  able  to  increase  its  loan  portfolio  by  36.3  percent  in  1996,  but  posted  negative
growth rates in 1997 and 1998 due to the Asian financial crisis. It posted a 3 percent growth rate
in 1999. Assuming economic recovery in Central Sulawesi Province, the BPD may be capable
of  duplicating  the  36  percent  growth  rate  of  its  loan  portfolio  in  1996.  However,  using
conservative  projections,  the  Mission  assumed  a  gradual  increase  of  10  percent  in  2000,  15
percent in 2001, 20 percent in 2002, and increases of 2 percent thereafter.

The results indicate that all six BPDs are viable in the long term. BPD Central Sulawesi,
which  received  a  “less  than  satisfactory”  rating  in  1999,  is  projected  to  obtain  a  “satisfactory”
rating in 2001 and 2002, the latter coinciding with the expected disbursement from the project
credit line in 2002.

F. 

Conclusions and Recommendations

22.
The Mission concludes that five of the six BPDs are in reasonable financial condition and
have good management in place. In the case of BPD Central Sulawesi, management appears
to  be  “satisfactory,”  but  an  improvement  in  performance  (reflected  in  the  CAMEL  rating)  will
need to take place. The Mission considers all the six BPDs qualified to participate in the Project
as  Executing  Banks  but  BPD  Central  Sulawesi  must  improve  its  Bank  Indonesia  rating  to
“satisfactory” before it can borrow credit funds from the Project. This condition is included in the
Loan Agreement. During project implementation, loan releases from the Project to the six BPDs
will also depend on their maintaining a satisfactory rating from Bank Indonesia. Analysis of the
viability of six BPDs based on financial projections indicates that they are all viable in the long
term.  BPD  Central  Sulawesi  is  projected  to  obtain  a  “satisfactory”  rating  in  2002  when  the
drawdown from the Project is targeted.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS

A. 

Capacity Building for Decentralized Planning

1.

Community Development Process Specialist (international, 38 person-
months)

1.
The  consultant  will  (i)  finalize  the  design  of  the  community  development  program,
detailed  implementation  schedule,  targets  and  cost  estimates,  using  the  community-based
planning mechanism (CBPM) approach and the community development working group (KKPM)
arrangement  under  part  A  of  the  Project;  and  emphasizing  full  community  participation  in
preparing  village  development  plans;  and    (ii)  conduct  workshops  and  training  for  government
officials, nongovernment organization (NGO) facilitators, and community leaders and members
to create awareness and to transfer skills in CBPM and KKPM processes.

2.        Capacity Building Training Specialist (international, 35 person-months)

The consultant will (i) develop the detailed six-month capacity-building training program
2.
for  communities,  aimed  at  preparing  village  development  plans;  develop  training  curricula  and
training modules for officials at various levels of government, NGO facilitators, and community,
with  particular  emphasis  on  the  needs  of  women  and  poor  members,  providing  detailed
implementation  schedule,  targets  and  cost  estimates;  and  (ii)  recommend  the  procurement
